preOperative.title: Dietary Preparation
preOperative.description: Avoid very hot or cold foods/drinks immediately before appointment if teeth are sensitive.

immediate.title: Avoid Chewing on Restoration
immediate.description: Do not chew hard foods or use the treated tooth for chewing until anesthesia wears off to avoid biting your lip or cheek.

first24Hours.title: Soft Diet
first24Hours.description: Stick to soft foods and avoid chewing on the treated tooth to allow the restoration to set properly.

first24Hours.title: Monitor for Pain
first24Hours.description: Some sensitivity is normal. Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen can help if needed.

firstWeek.title: Resume Normal Oral Hygiene
firstWeek.description: Continue regular brushing and flossing, but avoid vigorous brushing around the restoration site.

ongoing.title: Regular Dental Visits
ongoing.description: Schedule routine check-ups every 6 months to monitor the restoration and prevent recurrent caries.

foodsToEat: Soft foods like yogurt, applesauce, and soups during the first day
A balanced diet with adequate calcium and vitamin D for tooth remineralization
foodsToAvoid: Hard, crunchy foods like nuts and hard candies that could damage the restoration
Extremely hot or cold foods if sensitivity persists
Sugary foods and drinks to prevent recurrent caries
hydrationGuidelines: Maintain normal hydration; drink water regularly
Avoid sugary beverages

oralHygiene.title: Gentle Brushing
oralHygiene.description: Brush teeth gently twice daily with a soft-bristled toothbrush. Use fluoride toothpaste.

oralHygiene.title: Daily Flossing
oralHygiene.description: Floss daily to remove plaque between teeth and around restorations.

oralHygiene.title: Antimicrobial Mouthwash
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine mouthwash for 1 week if prescribed to reduce bacterial load.

painManagement.title: Over-the-Counter Pain Relief
painManagement.description: Take ibuprofen (400-600mg every 6-8 hours) or acetaminophen as needed for discomfort.

warningSigns.title: Severe or Persistent Pain
warningSigns.description: Seek immediate care if pain is severe, throbbing, or doesn't improve with medication.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Contact dentist if swelling, fever, or pus develops around the treated tooth.

warningSigns.title: Restoration Damage
warningSigns.description: If the filling chips or falls out, contact your dentist immediately.

preOperative.title: Improve Oral Hygiene
preOperative.description: Brush and floss thoroughly before your appointment to maximize treatment effectiveness.

immediate.title: Avoid Irritants
immediate.description: Avoid smoking, alcohol, and spicy foods that may irritate healing gums.

first24Hours.title: Gentle Oral Care
first24Hours.description: Use soft toothbrush and avoid vigorous brushing to prevent further irritation.

first24Hours.title: Cold Compress
first24Hours.description: Apply cold compress if swelling occurs to reduce inflammation.

firstWeek.title: Maintain Hygiene Routine
firstWeek.description: Continue gentle brushing and flossing as instructed.

ongoing.title: Professional Cleanings
ongoing.description: Schedule professional cleanings every 3-6 months to prevent recurrence.

foodsToEat: Anti-inflammatory foods like leafy greens, fatty fish, and berries
Crunchy vegetables like carrots and celery for natural cleaning
foodsToAvoid: Sugary foods and drinks that promote bacterial growth
Acidic foods and beverages that can irritate gums
Sticky foods that adhere to teeth and gums
hydrationGuidelines: Drink plenty of water to maintain oral moisture
Green tea has antioxidant properties beneficial for gum health

oralHygiene.title: Modified Bass Brushing Technique
oralHygiene.description: Brush teeth using the Bass technique: place bristles at 45-degree angle to gums, gently vibrate, then sweep away from gums.

oralHygiene.title: Interdental Cleaning
oralHygiene.description: Use interdental brushes or floss daily to clean between teeth where gingivitis often starts.

oralHygiene.title: Antimicrobial Mouth Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine gluconate 0.12% rinse twice daily for 2 weeks, then as directed.

painManagement.title: Anti-Inflammatory Medication
painManagement.description: NSAIDs like ibuprofen can help reduce inflammation and discomfort if needed.

warningSigns.title: Increased Bleeding
warningSigns.description: If bleeding persists or worsens after treatment, contact your dentist.

warningSigns.title: Severe Swelling or Pain
warningSigns.description: Seek immediate care if swelling increases or severe pain develops.

warningSigns.title: Systemic Symptoms
warningSigns.description: Fever, malaise, or spreading infection requires urgent medical attention.

preOperative.title: Pre-Appointment Pain Relief
preOperative.description: Take prescribed analgesics before your appointment if experiencing severe pain.

preOperative.title: Avoid Pain Triggers
preOperative.description: Avoid hot/cold foods and drinks that may trigger pain before treatment.

immediate.title: Anesthesia Care
immediate.description: Avoid eating until anesthesia wears off to prevent lip/tongue biting. Soft foods only.

first24Hours.title: Monitor Pain Levels
first24Hours.description: Pain should decrease significantly. Take prescribed pain medication as directed.

first24Hours.title: Head Elevation
first24Hours.description: Keep head elevated while sleeping to reduce swelling.

firstWeek.title: Soft Diet
firstWeek.description: Continue soft foods and avoid chewing on the treated tooth until permanent restoration.

ongoing.title: Complete Treatment
ongoing.description: Return for permanent crown or filling as scheduled to protect the tooth.

foodsToEat: Soft, cool foods like yogurt and smoothies
Room temperature foods to avoid thermal sensitivity
foodsToAvoid: Hot or cold foods/drinks that may cause sensitivity
Hard or crunchy foods that could damage temporary restoration
Sugary foods that promote bacterial growth
hydrationGuidelines: Drink water at room temperature
Avoid very hot beverages

oralHygiene.title: Gentle Brushing
oralHygiene.description: Brush gently around treated tooth. Use soft toothbrush.

oralHygiene.title: Saltwater Rinses
oralHygiene.description: Rinse with warm saltwater (1/2 tsp salt in 8oz water) 3-4 times daily to reduce inflammation.

oralHygiene.title: Protect Treated Tooth
oralHygiene.description: Avoid flossing treated tooth until permanent restoration is placed.

painManagement.title: Prescribed Pain Medication
painManagement.description: Take pain medication as prescribed. Ibuprofen is often preferred for its anti-inflammatory effects.

painManagement.title: Cold Therapy
painManagement.description: Apply cold compress externally for 15-20 minutes to reduce pain and swelling.

warningSigns.title: Severe or Worsening Pain
warningSigns.description: Contact dentist immediately if pain worsens or becomes unbearable.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Swelling, fever, or pus indicate infection requiring urgent care.

warningSigns.title: Temporary Restoration Failure
warningSigns.description: If temporary filling falls out, contact dentist to prevent contamination.

preOperative.title: Antibiotic Therapy
preOperative.description: Begin prescribed antibiotics as directed, usually 1 hour before procedure if applicable.

preOperative.title: Pre-Procedure Pain Management
preOperative.description: Take pain medication 30-60 minutes before appointment.

immediate.title: Pressure Application
immediate.description: Apply firm pressure with gauze for 30-45 minutes to control bleeding.

first24Hours.title: Ice Therapy
first24Hours.description: Apply ice packs externally for 15 minutes on, 15 minutes off to reduce swelling.

first24Hours.title: Rest and Elevation
first24Hours.description: Rest with head elevated to minimize swelling.

firstWeek.title: Soft Diet
firstWeek.description: Eat soft foods and avoid chewing near extraction site.

firstWeek.title: Complete Antibiotic Course
firstWeek.description: Finish all prescribed antibiotics even if symptoms improve.

ongoing.title: Follow-Up Care
ongoing.description: Attend all follow-up appointments to monitor healing and complete definitive treatment.

foodsToEat: Cold, soft foods like ice cream or yogurt to soothe the area
Nutritious soups and protein shakes for adequate nutrition
foodsToAvoid: Hot, spicy, or acidic foods that can irritate healing tissues
Hard, crunchy foods that may dislodge blood clot
Alcohol and carbonated drinks
hydrationGuidelines: Drink plenty of water but avoid using straws which can dislodge blood clot
Stay hydrated to support healing

oralHygiene.title: Gentle Rinsing
oralHygiene.description: Begin gentle saltwater rinses 24 hours after procedure (1/2 tsp salt in warm water).

oralHygiene.title: Protect Healing Site
oralHygiene.description: Avoid brushing extraction site for 24 hours, then brush gently.

oralHygiene.title: Antiseptic Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine rinse twice daily if prescribed to prevent infection.

painManagement.title: Pain Medication
painManagement.description: Take prescribed pain medication as directed. Combine acetaminophen and ibuprofen if recommended.

painManagement.title: Ice Packs
painManagement.description: Continue ice application for first 24 hours to manage swelling and pain.

warningSigns.title: Dry Socket
warningSigns.description: Severe pain 2-3 days after extraction may indicate dry socket; contact dentist immediately.

warningSigns.title: Persistent Bleeding
warningSigns.description: Bleeding that doesn't stop after 24 hours requires immediate attention.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Increasing swelling, fever, severe pain, or foul taste/smell indicate spreading infection.

warningSigns.title: Allergic Reaction
warningSigns.description: Rash, itching, swelling of face/tongue, or difficulty breathing require emergency care.

preOperative.title: Pre-Procedure Medication
preOperative.description: Take prescribed antibiotics or sedatives as directed before the appointment.

preOperative.title: Transportation Arrangements
preOperative.description: Arrange for someone to drive you home if sedation is used.

immediate.title: Bite on Gauze
immediate.description: Bite firmly on gauze for 30-45 minutes to control bleeding. Change as needed.

immediate.title: Immediate Rest
immediate.description: Rest quietly for the remainder of the day.

first24Hours.title: Ice Application
first24Hours.description: Apply ice packs to face for 15 minutes on, 15 minutes off to reduce swelling.

first24Hours.title: Head Elevation
first24Hours.description: Keep head elevated above heart level, even while sleeping, for 2-3 days.

first24Hours.title: No Rinsing
first24Hours.description: Do not rinse mouth, drink through straw, or smoke for 24 hours.

firstWeek.title: Soft Diet
firstWeek.description: Eat soft, cool foods. Avoid hot foods and alcohol.

firstWeek.title: Saltwater Rinses
firstWeek.description: Begin gentle saltwater rinses after 24 hours, 3-4 times daily.

firstWeek.title: Activity Restrictions
firstWeek.description: Avoid strenuous exercise, bending, or heavy lifting for 3-4 days.

ongoing.title: Monitor Healing
ongoing.description: Socket should fill with granulation tissue. Return for suture removal if applicable.

ongoing.title: Tooth Replacement
ongoing.description: Discuss tooth replacement options (implant, bridge, denture) at follow-up.

foodsToEat: Cold, soft foods like yogurt, ice cream, applesauce, and smoothies
Protein-rich foods like eggs, cheese, and nut butters
Soups and broths at room temperature
foodsToAvoid: Hot foods and beverages
Spicy, acidic, or rough foods that can irritate the socket
Small grains, seeds, or rice that can get stuck in socket
Alcohol and carbonated drinks
hydrationGuidelines: Drink plenty of water at room temperature
Avoid drinking through straws for first 24 hours to prevent dry socket

oralHygiene.title: Protect Extraction Site
oralHygiene.description: Do not brush extraction site for 24 hours. Brush other teeth normally.

oralHygiene.title: Saltwater Mouth Rinse
oralHygiene.description: After 24 hours, rinse gently with warm saltwater 3-4 times daily.

oralHygiene.title: Antiseptic Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use prescribed chlorhexidine rinse twice daily if antibiotics are given.

oralHygiene.title: No Smoking
oralHygiene.description: Do not smoke for at least 48 hours as it impairs healing.

painManagement.title: Prescribed Pain Medication
painManagement.description: Take pain medication as prescribed. Start before pain becomes severe.

painManagement.title: Alternating Pain Relief
painManagement.description: Alternate ibuprofen and acetaminophen if recommended by dentist.

warningSigns.title: Dry Socket
warningSigns.description: Severe pain 2-4 days after extraction, bad taste/smell. Contact dentist immediately.

warningSigns.title: Excessive Bleeding
warningSigns.description: Bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure. Seek immediate care.

warningSigns.title: Infection Signs
warningSigns.description: Fever, increasing swelling, severe pain, pus, or foul odor require urgent attention.

warningSigns.title: Persistent Numbness
warningSigns.description: If numbness persists beyond expected time, contact dentist.

warningSigns.title: Allergic Reaction
warningSigns.description: Rash, hives, swelling, or difficulty breathing require emergency care.

preOperative.title: Pre-Procedure Medications
preOperative.description: Take prescribed antibiotics if infection is present, and pain medication 30-60 minutes before appointment.

preOperative.title: Eat Before Appointment
preOperative.description: Eat a light meal before the appointment, especially if sedation is planned.

immediate.title: Anesthesia Precautions
immediate.description: Avoid eating until numbness wears off. Start with soft foods.

immediate.title: Temporary Restoration Care
immediate.description: Temporary filling may feel different. Avoid chewing hard foods on it.

first24Hours.title: Pain Assessment
first24Hours.description: Some discomfort is normal. Take pain medication as prescribed.

first24Hours.title: Head Elevation
first24Hours.description: Sleep with head elevated to reduce swelling.

firstWeek.title: Soft Diet
firstWeek.description: Continue soft foods. Avoid chewing on treated tooth until permanent restoration.

firstWeek.title: Oral Hygiene
firstWeek.description: Maintain excellent oral hygiene to prevent reinfection.

ongoing.title: Permanent Restoration
ongoing.description: Return for crown placement within 2-4 weeks to protect the tooth.

ongoing.title: Regular Monitoring
ongoing.description: Annual check-ups to monitor endodontic success.

foodsToEat: Soft foods at comfortable temperatures
Nutritious meals to support healing
Cold foods if swelling occurs
foodsToAvoid: Hard, crunchy, or sticky foods that could damage temporary restoration
Very hot or cold foods if sensitivity persists
Sugary foods that promote bacterial growth
hydrationGuidelines: Maintain adequate hydration
Drink water regularly

oralHygiene.title: Gentle Brushing
oralHygiene.description: Brush gently around treated tooth. Use soft toothbrush.

oralHygiene.title: Careful Flossing
oralHygiene.description: Floss carefully around treated tooth. Avoid vigorous flossing.

oralHygiene.title: Antimicrobial Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine rinse twice daily for 1 week if prescribed.

painManagement.title: Scheduled Pain Relief
painManagement.description: Take pain medication on a schedule for first 24-48 hours, then as needed.

painManagement.title: Anti-Inflammatory Medication
painManagement.description: Ibuprofen helps reduce inflammation and pain following root canal.

warningSigns.title: Severe Pain
warningSigns.description: Pain that worsens or doesn't improve with medication requires immediate evaluation.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Increasing swelling, fever, or pus indicate failed treatment or infection.

warningSigns.title: Temporary Restoration Issues
warningSigns.description: If temporary filling falls out, contact dentist immediately to prevent contamination.

warningSigns.title: Persistent Numbness
warningSigns.description: Numbness lasting more than 24 hours after local anesthesia should be reported.

preOperative.title: Baseline Oral Hygiene
preOperative.description: Demonstrate good oral hygiene before starting therapy for optimal results.

preOperative.title: Smoking Cessation
preOperative.description: Quit smoking at least 1 week before treatment to improve healing.

immediate.title: Gentle Oral Care
immediate.description: Avoid vigorous brushing or flossing in treated areas for 24 hours.

first24Hours.title: Cold Application
first24Hours.description: Apply cold compress if swelling occurs to reduce discomfort.

first24Hours.title: Soft Diet
first24Hours.description: Choose soft foods that don't irritate healing gums.

firstWeek.title: Modified Hygiene Routine
firstWeek.description: Use soft toothbrush and gentle techniques. Avoid interdental cleaning in tender areas.

firstWeek.title: Medication Compliance
firstWeek.description: Take all prescribed antibiotics and pain medication as directed.

ongoing.title: Supportive Periodontal Therapy
ongoing.description: Attend regular maintenance appointments every 3-4 months.

ongoing.title: Lifestyle Changes
ongoing.description: Maintain excellent oral hygiene and address risk factors like smoking.

foodsToEat: Anti-inflammatory foods: fatty fish, nuts, olive oil, colorful vegetables
Vitamin C-rich foods: citrus fruits, bell peppers, broccoli
Vitamin D sources: fortified foods, sunlight exposure
foodsToAvoid: Sugary foods and drinks that feed harmful bacteria
Acidic foods that can irritate healing gums
Hard foods that may traumatize healing tissues
hydrationGuidelines: Drink plenty of water to maintain oral health
Green tea may have beneficial antioxidant properties
supplements: Vitamin C (500-1000mg daily) may support gum healing
Vitamin D if deficient, as determined by blood test

oralHygiene.title: Modified Bass Technique
oralHygiene.description: Use gentle Bass brushing technique with soft toothbrush, 2 minutes twice daily.

oralHygiene.title: Interdental Cleaning
oralHygiene.description: Use interdental brushes or floss once daily. Start gently if tender.

oralHygiene.title: Antimicrobial Mouth Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine 0.12% twice daily for 2-4 weeks, then maintenance rinse.

oralHygiene.title: Tongue Cleaning
oralHygiene.description: Clean tongue daily to reduce bacterial load.

painManagement.title: Over-the-Counter Pain Relief
painManagement.description: Use ibuprofen or acetaminophen for discomfort. Take with food.

warningSigns.title: Increased Bleeding
warningSigns.description: Bleeding that persists beyond 1 week or worsens requires evaluation.

warningSigns.title: Severe Pain
warningSigns.description: Severe or worsening pain may indicate infection or other complications.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Fever, swelling, pus, or foul taste/smell require immediate care.

warningSigns.title: Increasing Tooth Mobility
warningSigns.description: If teeth feel looser after treatment, contact dentist promptly.

preOperative.title: Pre-Surgical Rinse
preOperative.description: Use chlorhexidine rinse twice daily for 1 week before surgery.

preOperative.title: Smoking Cessation
preOperative.description: Stop smoking at least 2 weeks before and after surgery to ensure healing.

preOperative.title: Antibiotic Prophylaxis
preOperative.description: Take prescribed antibiotics as directed before surgery.

immediate.title: Bleeding Control
immediate.description: Apply firm pressure with gauze for 30-45 minutes. Change as needed.

immediate.title: Immediate Ice Therapy
immediate.description: Apply ice packs for 15 minutes on, 15 minutes off for first 24 hours.

first24Hours.title: Rest and Elevation
first24Hours.description: Rest with head elevated. Avoid strenuous activity.

first24Hours.title: No Rinsing/Smoking
first24Hours.description: Do not rinse vigorously, smoke, or use straws for 24 hours.

firstWeek.title: Soft Diet
firstWeek.description: Eat soft, cool foods. Avoid hot foods near surgical site.

firstWeek.title: Gentle Oral Care
firstWeek.description: Begin gentle saltwater rinses after 24 hours, 3-4 times daily.

firstWeek.title: Medication Compliance
firstWeek.description: Continue antibiotics and pain medication as prescribed.

ongoing.title: Healing Phase
ongoing.description: Allow 3-6 months for osseointegration before restorative phase.

ongoing.title: Implant Maintenance
ongoing.description: Schedule regular check-ups and professional cleanings every 6 months.

foodsToEat: Protein-rich soft foods: yogurt, cottage cheese, scrambled eggs
Calcium and vitamin D-rich foods: fortified plant milks, leafy greens
Soft fruits and vegetables
foodsToAvoid: Hard, crunchy foods that could damage surgical site
Hot, spicy foods that may irritate healing tissues
Alcohol and carbonated drinks
hydrationGuidelines: Drink plenty of water to support healing
Avoid straws for first 24 hours
supplements: Calcium (1000mg daily) and vitamin D (800-1000 IU) for bone healing
Consider vitamin C for tissue repair

oralHygiene.title: Surgical Site Protection
oralHygiene.description: Avoid brushing surgical site for 24 hours. Use soft toothbrush elsewhere.

oralHygiene.title: Saltwater Rinses
oralHygiene.description: After 24 hours, rinse gently with warm saltwater 3-4 times daily.

oralHygiene.title: Chlorhexidine Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine 0.12% twice daily for 1-2 weeks.

oralHygiene.title: No Smoking
oralHygiene.description: Do not smoke for at least 2 weeks to promote healing.

painManagement.title: Prescribed Pain Medication
painManagement.description: Take pain medication as prescribed. Start before pain becomes severe.

painManagement.title: Continued Ice Therapy
painManagement.description: Continue ice application for first 48 hours to manage swelling.

warningSigns.title: Implant Mobility
warningSigns.description: If implant feels loose, contact dentist immediately.

warningSigns.title: Severe Pain
warningSigns.description: Pain that worsens after 3-4 days may indicate complications.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Fever, increasing swelling, pus, redness around implant site.

warningSigns.title: Nerve Involvement
warningSigns.description: Numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in lips/chin requires immediate attention.

warningSigns.title: Sinus Issues
warningSigns.description: If upper implant placement, watch for nasal discharge or voice changes.

preOperative.title: Pre-Surgical Rinse
preOperative.description: Use chlorhexidine rinse twice daily for 1 week before surgery.

preOperative.title: Smoking Cessation
preOperative.description: Stop smoking at least 1 week before surgery.

preOperative.title: Arrange Post-Operative Care
preOperative.description: Arrange for someone to stay with you for 24 hours after surgery.

immediate.title: Gauze Pressure
immediate.description: Bite firmly on gauze packs for 45-60 minutes. Change as needed.

immediate.title: Immediate Ice Application
immediate.description: Apply ice packs immediately and continue for first 24 hours.

first24Hours.title: Bed Rest
first24Hours.description: Rest in bed with head elevated above heart level.

first24Hours.title: No Straws/Smoking
first24Hours.description: Do not use straws, smoke, or drink alcohol for 24 hours.

first24Hours.title: Scheduled Pain Medication
first24Hours.description: Take pain medication on schedule, before pain becomes severe.

firstWeek.title: Soft Diet
firstWeek.description: Eat soft, cool foods. Avoid hot, spicy, or acidic foods.

firstWeek.title: Gentle Oral Care
firstWeek.description: Begin gentle saltwater rinses after 24 hours, 3-4 times daily.

firstWeek.title: Limited Activity
firstWeek.description: Avoid strenuous exercise, bending, heavy lifting for 3-4 days.

ongoing.title: Socket Healing
ongoing.description: Extraction sites should heal within 1-2 weeks. Return for suture removal.

ongoing.title: Follow-Up Appointment
ongoing.description: Attend follow-up appointment 1 week after surgery.

foodsToEat: Cold, soft foods: ice cream, yogurt, smoothies, applesauce
Protein-rich foods: scrambled eggs, cottage cheese, protein shakes
Soups and broths at room temperature
foodsToAvoid: Hot foods and beverages
Spicy, acidic, or rough foods
Small grains, seeds, nuts that can get stuck in sockets
Alcohol and carbonated drinks
hydrationGuidelines: Drink plenty of water at room temperature
Avoid straws and carbonated drinks for first 24 hours

oralHygiene.title: Protect Surgical Sites
oralHygiene.description: Do not brush extraction sites for 24 hours. Brush other teeth normally.

oralHygiene.title: Saltwater Mouth Rinses
oralHygiene.description: After 24 hours, rinse gently with warm saltwater 3-4 times daily for 1 week.

oralHygiene.title: Chlorhexidine Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine 0.12% twice daily for 1 week.

oralHygiene.title: No Smoking/Vaping
oralHygiene.description: Do not smoke or vape for at least 48 hours, preferably 1 week.

painManagement.title: Prescribed Pain Medication
painManagement.description: Take prescribed pain medication regularly for first 48 hours.

painManagement.title: Anti-Inflammatory Drugs
painManagement.description: Ibuprofen is preferred for its swelling reduction effects.

warningSigns.title: Dry Socket
warningSigns.description: Severe pain 2-4 days after surgery with bad taste/smell. Contact dentist immediately.

warningSigns.title: Excessive Bleeding
warningSigns.description: Bleeding that doesn't stop with pressure or soaks through gauze.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Fever over 101Â°F, increasing swelling, severe pain, pus, foul odor.

warningSigns.title: Limited Jaw Opening
warningSigns.description: Difficulty opening mouth beyond 1 inch after 3-4 days.

warningSigns.title: Nerve Damage Signs
warningSigns.description: Persistent numbness, tingling in tongue, lips, or chin.

preOperative.title: Oral Hygiene Preparation
preOperative.description: Establish excellent oral hygiene routine before starting treatment.

preOperative.title: Dietary Adjustments
preOperative.description: Avoid hard, sticky foods that could damage appliances.

immediate.title: Appliance Adjustment
immediate.description: Expect some discomfort as teeth begin moving. Use prescribed wax for irritation.

first24Hours.title: Pain Management
first24Hours.description: Take over-the-counter pain relievers as needed for discomfort.

first24Hours.title: Soft Diet
first24Hours.description: Eat soft foods to avoid stressing new appliances.

firstWeek.title: Enhanced Oral Hygiene
firstWeek.description: Brush after every meal. Use floss threaders and interdental brushes.

firstWeek.title: Appliance Care
firstWeek.description: Avoid hard, sticky foods. Wear appliances as prescribed.

ongoing.title: Regular Appointments
ongoing.description: Attend adjustment appointments every 4-6 weeks as scheduled.

ongoing.title: Retention
ongoing.description: Wear retainers full-time initially, then nightly long-term.

foodsToEat: Soft foods during initial adjustment period
Nutritious meals to support bone health: calcium-rich foods, vitamin D sources
Cut foods into small pieces if needed
foodsToAvoid: Hard foods: nuts, hard candies, ice, raw carrots
Sticky foods: gum, caramel, taffy
Chewy foods: bagels, tough meats
Sugary foods that increase caries risk
hydrationGuidelines: Maintain good hydration
Drink water regularly to clean around appliances
supplements: Calcium and vitamin D supplements if dietary intake is inadequate

oralHygiene.title: Special Brushing Technique
oralHygiene.description: Brush after every meal for 2 minutes. Use orthodontic toothbrush.

oralHygiene.title: Flossing with Threaders
oralHygiene.description: Use floss threaders to clean under wires. Floss daily.

oralHygiene.title: Interdental Brushes
oralHygiene.description: Use interdental brushes to clean between brackets and wires.

oralHygiene.title: Fluoride Mouthwash
oralHygiene.description: Use fluoride rinse daily to strengthen teeth and prevent decalcification.

painManagement.title: Over-the-Counter Pain Relief
painManagement.description: Use ibuprofen or acetaminophen for orthodontic discomfort.

painManagement.title: Orthodontic Wax
painManagement.description: Apply wax to brackets causing irritation.

warningSigns.title: Severe Pain
warningSigns.description: Pain that doesn't improve with medication or lasts more than 1 week.

warningSigns.title: Loose Appliances
warningSigns.description: If brackets or wires become loose, contact orthodontist immediately.

warningSigns.title: Soft Tissue Injury
warningSigns.description: Ulcers or cuts in mouth that don't heal within 1-2 weeks.

warningSigns.title: Allergic Reaction
warningSigns.description: Rash, swelling, or itching from appliances requires immediate attention.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Complications
warningSigns.description: Unusual tooth mobility or severe pain may indicate complications.

preOperative.title: Tooth Preparation
preOperative.description: Temporary restoration may be placed. Avoid chewing on it until final restoration.

immediate.title: Anesthesia Precautions
immediate.description: Avoid eating until numbness wears off to prevent injury.

immediate.title: Temporary Restoration Care
immediate.description: Be gentle with temporary crown. Avoid sticky/hard foods.

first24Hours.title: Pain Assessment
first24Hours.description: Some sensitivity is normal. Take pain medication as prescribed.

first24Hours.title: Soft Diet
first24Hours.description: Eat soft foods and chew on opposite side of mouth.

firstWeek.title: Oral Hygiene
firstWeek.description: Maintain excellent hygiene. Brush and floss carefully around temporary.

firstWeek.title: Avoid Irritants
firstWeek.description: Avoid very hot/cold foods that may cause sensitivity.

ongoing.title: Final Restoration
ongoing.description: Return for placement of permanent crown/bridge as scheduled.

ongoing.title: Long-Term Maintenance
ongoing.description: Practice excellent oral hygiene. Schedule regular check-ups.

foodsToEat: Soft foods during temporary phase
Balanced diet for overall health
Foods that don't require excessive chewing on treated side
foodsToAvoid: Hard, crunchy foods that could damage temporary restoration
Sticky foods like gum or caramel that could dislodge temporary
Very hot or cold foods if sensitivity occurs
hydrationGuidelines: Maintain normal hydration
Drink water to help clean around restorations

oralHygiene.title: Gentle Brushing
oralHygiene.description: Brush gently around temporary restoration. Use soft toothbrush.

oralHygiene.title: Careful Flossing
oralHygiene.description: Floss carefully around temporary. Use floss threaders if needed.

oralHygiene.title: Antimicrobial Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use chlorhexidine rinse twice daily if gum inflammation is present.

painManagement.title: Over-the-Counter Medication
painManagement.description: Use ibuprofen or acetaminophen for discomfort as needed.

warningSigns.title: Loose Temporary
warningSigns.description: If temporary crown/bridge becomes loose, contact dentist immediately.

warningSigns.title: Severe Pain
warningSigns.description: Pain that worsens or doesn't improve with medication.

warningSigns.title: Gum Inflammation
warningSigns.description: Red, swollen gums around temporary that persist.

warningSigns.title: Allergic Reaction
warningSigns.description: Rash, swelling, or itching from materials used.

preOperative.title: Behavioral Preparation
preOperative.description: Discuss treatment with child using age-appropriate language. Use positive reinforcement.

preOperative.title: Parent Involvement
preOperative.description: Parents should stay with child during treatment for comfort and support.

immediate.title: Comfort Care
immediate.description: Provide comfort items like favorite toys or blankets. Praise good behavior.

immediate.title: Anesthesia Monitoring
immediate.description: Monitor for return of sensation. Avoid hot foods until normal feeling returns.

first24Hours.title: Pain Management
first24Hours.description: Give prescribed pain medication on schedule. Use appropriate dosing for age/weight.

first24Hours.title: Soft Diet
first24Hours.description: Provide soft, cool foods. Avoid hard or crunchy foods.

firstWeek.title: Age-Appropriate Hygiene
firstWeek.description: Assist with gentle brushing and flossing. Use child-sized toothbrush.

firstWeek.title: Positive Reinforcement
firstWeek.description: Praise good oral hygiene habits. Make brushing fun.

ongoing.title: Regular Dental Visits
ongoing.description: Schedule recall visits every 6 months for prevention and monitoring.

ongoing.title: Fluoride Supplementation
ongoing.description: Use fluoride supplements or toothpaste as recommended for caries prevention.

foodsToEat: Calcium-rich foods: milk, cheese, yogurt for developing teeth
Crunchy vegetables for natural cleaning (supervised)
Balanced meals with adequate nutrients for growth
foodsToAvoid: Sugary snacks and drinks between meals
Sticky foods that adhere to teeth
Carbonated drinks that can erode enamel
hydrationGuidelines: Drink fluoridated water if available
Limit sugary drinks; encourage water and milk
supplements: Fluoride supplements if water is not fluoridated

oralHygiene.title: Supervised Brushing
oralHygiene.description: Parents should supervise brushing until age 8-10. Use pea-sized amount of fluoride toothpaste.

oralHygiene.title: Flossing Training
oralHygiene.description: Teach proper flossing technique. Assist until child can do independently.

oralHygiene.title: Fluoride Rinse
oralHygiene.description: Use age-appropriate fluoride mouth rinse daily under supervision.

oralHygiene.title: Sealant Care
oralHygiene.description: Avoid chewing ice or hard objects that could damage sealants.

painManagement.title: Age-Appropriate Pain Relief
painManagement.description: Use ibuprofen or acetaminophen dosed by weight. Follow pediatric dosing guidelines.

painManagement.title: Non-Pharmacologic Comfort
painManagement.description: Use distraction, favorite toys, or cold treats for comfort.

warningSigns.title: Persistent Pain
warningSigns.description: Pain that lasts more than 2-3 days or worsens requires evaluation.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Infection
warningSigns.description: Fever, facial swelling, or pus indicates infection needing immediate care.

warningSigns.title: Behavioral Changes
warningSigns.description: Sudden fear of dental procedures or refusal to eat may indicate pain.

warningSigns.title: Allergic Reaction
warningSigns.description: Rash, swelling, or breathing difficulties from medications or materials.

warningSigns.title: Signs of Trauma
warningSigns.description: Avulsed tooth or severe injury requires immediate emergency care.
